Description: The total capacity of a cache, derived from the number of blocks and the block size.
Constraints: Must be discoverable by software via the execution environment; no upper/lower bound specified in this excerpt

Description: The structural organization of a cache (e.g., direct‑mapped, set‑associative) that determines how blocks are mapped to sets or ways.
Constraints: Not specified; arrangement is left to the implementation and must be discoverable by software via the execution environment.

Description: The size of each cache block, which represents a contiguous, naturally aligned power‑of‑two (or NAPOT) range of memory locations.
Constraints: ['Must be a contiguous, naturally aligned power-of-two (NAPOT) range of memory locations.', 'For systems supporting the initial set of CMO extensions, the size must be uniform throughout the system.']
Keywords: implementation-specific, shall be uniform, uniform, shall be uniform, cache block, implementation-specific, implementation-specific, uniform, power-of-two, NAPOT, contiguous, size, NAPOT, power-of-two, shall

Description: The alignment requirement for cache blocks, which must be naturally aligned to a power‑of‑two boundary (or NAPOT).
Constraints: Must be naturally aligned (address multiple of block size); implied by "naturally aligned power-of-two range"
Keywords: may, naturally aligned, naturally aligned power-of-two (or NAPOT), contiguous, NAPOT, power-of-two, aligned

Description: Software-accessible method (e.g., CSR, memory-mapped register, HSM, or OS interface) to query cache parameters
Constraints: The execution environment *must* provide such a mechanism ("provides software a means to discover"); but the mechanism itself is not standardized in this spec excerpt
Keywords: execution environment provides software a means to discover, implementation-specific, provides software a means to discover, provides, discover

Description: Whether cache blocks map to contiguous, naturally aligned power-of-two (NAPOT) ranges or other range types
Constraints: The spec explicitly allows "power-of-two (or NAPOT)" — suggesting NAPOT is one valid option among others (though not elaborated here); no requirement to support both

Description: How a cache block is identified — specifically, whether identification uses any physical address in the block
Constraints: Must allow identification by *any* physical address in the block; no restriction on internal tagging scheme
Keywords: corresponding to the underlying memory locations, identified by any of the physical addresses

Description: Whether the size of a cache block is uniform throughout the system
Constraints: Shall be uniform in the initial set of CMO extensions

Description: The total number of available CSR encodings within the 12-bit encoding space.
Constraints: Maximum of 4,096 CSRs (12-bit encoding space)
Keywords: sets aside, up to, encoding space, up to

Description: The use of CSR bits [9:8] to encode the lowest privilege level permitted to access a CSR, following the conventional address-mapping scheme.
Constraints: These two bits must provide an encoding of the lowest privilege level that can access the CSR, as specified by the conventional layout.
Keywords: By convention, encode the lowest privilege level

Description: Whether to follow the conventional CSR accessibility encoding scheme
Constraints: By convention, not required by standard

Description: Number of bits used for encoding CSR accessibility levels
Constraints: Upper 4 bits (csr[11:8]) used in conventional scheme

Description: Encoding scheme for read/write vs read-only CSR classification
Constraints: Bits csr[11:10]: 00,01,10 for read/write; 11 for read-only

Description: Encoding scheme for minimum privilege level required to access CSR
Constraints: Bits csr[9:8] encode lowest privilege level

Description: Mapping between privilege levels and CSR accessibility
Constraints: Must follow encoding in bits csr[9:8] if convention adopted

Description: Number of bits used for the CSR address field.
Constraints: Defined as a 12‑bit space, supporting up to 4096 distinct CSRs.

Description: Encoding of read/write accessibility using the upper 4 bits of the CSR address.
Constraints: Bits csr[11:8] encode the accessibility (read/write or read‑only) according to privilege level.
Keywords: upper 4 bits, privilege level, read/write accessibility

Description: Encoding that indicates whether a CSR is read/write or read‑only.
Constraints: Values 00, 01, or 10 in csr[11:10] mean read/write; 11 means read‑only.

Description: Encoding of the lowest privilege level that may access a CSR.
Constraints: Bits csr[9:8] specify the minimum privilege level required to access the CSR.

Description: Maximum number of distinct CSRs that can be defined.
Constraints: Maximum of 4096 CSRs (2^12).

Description: The scheme used to map CSR addresses to accessibility and privilege requirements.
Constraints: May be defined by convention; implementations may choose alternative mappings.

Description: The interpretation of CSR bits [11:10] for distinguishing read/write versus read-only registers, which is defined by convention rather than mandated.
Constraints: When used, the top two bits should encode read/write states as 00, 01, or 10 for registers that allow writes, and 11 for read-only registers, following the conventional mapping.

Description: Whether the implementation follows the "conventional" R/W and privilege level mapping for CSR addresses.
Constraints: Uses csr[11:8] to encode accessibility and privilege level.
Keywords: By convention, shown in Table 1, Conventional

Description: Implementation of the read-only restriction for CSRs where the top two bits (csr[11:10]) are set to 11.
Constraints: Bits 11 and 10 must be 11 to indicate read-only status.

Description: The mapping of the lowest privilege level allowed to access a CSR based on address bits csr[9:8].
Constraints: Encoded in bits 9 and 8 of the CSR address.

Description: The size of the encoding space reserved for CSRs.
Constraints: ['12-bit encoding space (csr[11:0])', 'up to 4,096 CSRs']

Description: The convention for using the upper bits of the CSR address to encode read/write accessibility and privilege level.
Constraints: ['upper 4 bits of the CSR address (csr[11:8]) are used', 'top two bits (csr[11:10]) indicate read/write (00,01, or 10) or read-only (11)', 'next two bits (csr[9:8]) encode the lowest privilege level that can access the CSR']
Keywords: By convention, are used to encode

Description: The encoding scheme within the top two bits (csr[11:10]) of the CSR address to indicate read/write or read-only status.
Constraints: ['00, 01, or 10 for read/write', '11 for read-only']
